title: Pommiers en fleurs (Apple Trees in Blossom; Le Printemps; Springtime)
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Gloria Groom.

Gloria Groom: So this is Pommiers en fleurs and it’s important for many reasons. It’s important in the exhibition because it really gets us into the story of Monet in Chicago.

Narrator: Research Associate Kathryn Kremnitzer.

Kathryn Kremnitzer: Apple Trees in Blossom is the first painting by Monet to be purchased by a
Chicago institution. In 1895, the Union League Club of Chicago purchased the painting from one of its
members, whose name is Judge John Barton Payne, and we know that they bought the painting for five
hundred dollars, and that reactions at the time were mixed. The president of the club at the time was not so much a fan of the work or of Monet in general and scoffed, “Who would pay five hundred dollars for that blob of paint?”

Gloria Groom: It’s a wonderful tie-in with the Art Institute because several of our trustees were also on
the board of the Union League Club, so there is this kind of synergy between these two important cultural institutions in Chicago.

Kathryn Kremnitzer: Another interesting fact to consider is that the painting was included in Monet’s first solo exhibition at a U.S. museum. It was shown at the Art Institute in March of 1895, which was organized by Paul Durand-Ruel.

Gloria Groom: Durand-Ruel was Monet’s most important dealer throughout his career, really, and who
really made the connections with America at a time when Monet was almost against having his paintings
come to America because he wanted them to be known in France, but Durand-Ruel was smart enough to
know that the audience was across the ocean.

Kathryn Kremnitzer: So it’s because of Durand-Ruel that Monet has become a household name, not
only in France, but particularly in the United States.
